clinical_study.brief_title: Dynamic Arterial Elastance to Predict Postural Change Induced Hypotension
clinical_study.official_title: Investigation on Dynamic Arterial Elastance as a Predictor of Hypotension Caused by the Positional Change From Supine to Prone (SuProne Study).

brief_summary.textblock: During general anesthesia, hypotension might occur during positional change. It is reported that hypotension after positional change from supine to prone is mainly caused by the decrease in preload. The investigators aimed to investigate whether dynamic arterial elastance might predict hypotension associated with positional change from supine to prone.

primary_outcome.measure: Dynamic arterial elastance before positional change
primary_outcome.description: Dynamic arterial elastance, defined as the ratio of pulse pressure variance/stroke volume variance will be recorded 1 minute before positional change

arm_group.description: Mean blood pressure is maintained after positional change from supine to prone.
Mean blood pressure decrease < 20% after positional change from supine to prone.

intervention.intervention_name: Positional change from supine to prone
intervention.description: Patient is turned from supine to prone position for spine surgery

study_pop.textblock: Patients who are scheduled for spine surgery and need positional change from supine to prone positioin.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patients planned for invasive arterial catheter insertion, undergoing elective spine surgery in prone position under general anesthesia
Exclusion Criteria:
- arrythmia
- pulmonary disease
- increased intracranial pressure
- decreased cardiac function (ejection fraction < 50%)
- obesity (body mass index > 40)
